shortDescription: The world's largest castle by land area and Europe's largest brick castle, Malbork was built by the Teutonic Knights as their headquarters. This massive red brick complex served as the center of the Teutonic Order's power in the Baltic region and stands as the ultimate example of medieval brick construction techniques.
keyFeatures: Largest castle in the world by land area
Eight massive towers and high curtain walls

heritageStatus.unescoDetails: Inscribed 1997 - Castle of the Teutonic Order in Malbork

shortDescription: Built by Edward I during his conquest of Wales, Conwy Castle stands as one of the finest examples of 13th-century military architecture in Europe. With its eight massive towers and high curtain walls, it forms part of Edward I's 'iron ring' of castles designed to control Wales.
keyFeatures: Part of Edward I's 'iron ring' of Welsh castles

shortDescription: Sprawling over 30 acres, Caerphilly Castle is the largest castle in Wales and the second-largest in Britain. This masterpiece of medieval military engineering features an elaborate system of moats and fortifications, with its leaning tower that out-leans Pisa's famous tower.

The fortified city of Carcassonne is a medieval marvel with its double ring of ramparts and 53 towers creating an imposing silhouette. Restored by Eugène Viollet-le-Duc in the 19th century, this UNESCO World Heritage site represents one of France's most complete examples of medieval fortification.

Founded by Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Bohemia, Karlštejn was built to safeguard the imperial regalia and holy relics. This Gothic castle represents the 'castliest castle of them all' with its fairy-tale appearance and perfectly preserved medieval interiors including the stunning Chapel of the Holy Cross.
keyFeatures: Built for Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor
Treasury for imperial regalia and holy relics
Chapel of the Holy Cross with precious stones

shortDescription: One of Japan's most famous castles, Osaka Castle was originally built by Toyotomi Hideyoshi as the centerpiece of his campaign to unify Japan. The current ferro-concrete reconstruction houses a modern museum while maintaining the castle's iconic five-story, eight-level structure with its distinctive green roof and golden ornaments.
keyFeatures: Distinctive green roof and golden ornaments

shortDescription: Considered one of Japan's three premier castles alongside Osaka and Nagoya, Kumamoto Castle is renowned for its sophisticated defensive design and curved stone walls called 'musha-gaeshi' that prevented enemy climbing. The castle offers spectacular 360-degree views from its top floors.
keyFeatures: One of Japan's three premier castles

shortDescription: The largest of the Five Grand Palaces built during the Joseon Dynasty, Gyeongbokgung served as the main royal palace for over 500 years. Famous for its changing of the guard ceremony and beautiful pavilions set around courtyards, it represents the pinnacle of Korean royal architecture.
keyFeatures: Main royal palace of Joseon Dynasty

specialTours: Changing of the Guard ceremony at 10:00, 14:00, 15:30

shortDescription: The imperial palace complex that served as home to 24 Ming and Qing dynasty emperors for over 500 years. Covering 720,000 square meters with 980 buildings, it's the world's most-visited palace and represents the pinnacle of traditional Chinese palatial architecture.

Built by newspaper tycoon William Randolph Hearst and architect Julia Morgan, this extravagant estate nicknamed 'La Cuesta Encantada' (The Enchanted Hill) features 165 rooms, world-class art collections, and 127 acres of terraced gardens overlooking the Pacific Coast.

Hotel magnate George C. Boldt began building this 120-room castle as a summer home for his beloved wife Louise. When she died before completion, construction halted for 70 years until restoration began, creating one of the most romantic castle stories in America.

This zany, medieval-inspired fortress was dreamed up by William Gillette, famous playwright and Sherlock Holmes actor. Built as his retirement home, the castle features 47 unique doors, secret passages, hidden rooms, and thousands of hand-crafted details that reflect Gillette's theatrical personality.

currentStatus.management: Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection

location: Pollepel Island, Hudson River, New York
shortDescription: Built by arms dealer Francis Bannerman VI as an ammunition storage facility and summer residence, this Scottish-style castle with turrets, towers, and a moat was largely destroyed by fire but remains a haunting ruin accessible only by boat tours through the Hudson River.

architecturalStyle: Mission Revival and Spanish Colonial Revival
shortDescription: Despite its name, this Spanish Colonial Revival villa with two tall towers was actually built by wealthy couple Albert and Bessie Johnson as a vacation home. The legend of 'Death Valley Scotty' claiming ownership created one of America's most colorful castle stories.
keyFeatures: Colorful legend of Death Valley Scotty
Built by Albert and Bessie Johnson

conservationProjects.scope: Structural repairs from 2015 flash flood damage

shortDescription: One of the most important preserved medieval castles in the world, Krak des Chevaliers was built by the Knights Hospitaller during the Crusades. This massive fortress represents the pinnacle of medieval military architecture and engineering in the Middle East.
keyFeatures: Most important preserved medieval castle worldwide

heritageStatus.unescoDetails: Ancient City of Aleppo and Crac des Chevaliers

shortDescription: The largest ancient structure south of the Sahara Desert, Great Zimbabwe was the capital of the Kingdom of Zimbabwe. These impressive stone walls built without mortar represent the pinnacle of indigenous African architecture and gave the modern country its name.
keyFeatures: Largest ancient structure south of Sahara

currentStatus.management: National Museums and Monuments of Zimbabwe

architecturalStyle: Ethiopian imperial architecture (Arab, Nubian, Gothic blend)
shortDescription: The fortress-city of Fasil Ghebbi in Gondar was founded by Emperor Fasilides and served as the residence of Ethiopian emperors. This unique architectural complex blends Arab, Nubian, and Gothic styles, representing the cosmopolitan nature of the Ethiopian Empire.
keyFeatures: Blend of Arab, Nubian, and Gothic architecture

currentStatus.management: Authority for Research and Conservation of Cultural Heritage

shortDescription: Built by Mamluk Sultan Qaitbay on the exact site of the ancient Lighthouse of Alexandria (one of the Seven Wonders), this fortress guarded Alexandria's harbor for centuries. The citadel incorporates stones from the fallen lighthouse into its construction.
keyFeatures: Built on site of ancient Lighthouse of Alexandria
Incorporates stones from the fallen lighthouse

currentStatus.management: Egyptian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities

shortDescription: This fortified village (ksar) along the former caravan route between the Sahara and Marrakech represents traditional pre-Saharan habitat. Built with mud brick, clay, and straw, it's one of Morocco's most photographed locations and a popular filming location.
keyFeatures: Built with mud brick, clay, and straw

currentStatus.management: Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports

shortDescription: Built to defend Lisbon's harbor and commemorate Vasco da Gama's expedition, this elegant tower represents the Manueline style at its finest. The tower served as both fortress and ceremonial gateway to Lisbon during Portugal's Age of Discovery.

Known as the 'Ladies' Castle' due to the influential women who shaped its history, Chenonceau spans the River Cher with its distinctive arched bridge gallery. This elegant château represents the height of French Renaissance architecture and is the most visited château in France after Versailles.
keyFeatures: Spans the River Cher with arched bridge
Rich history of influential women owners
